UBS Weekly FX Flows: USD most sold as commodity bloc bid
content: USD sold for 2nd straight week amid broad buying interest in commodity blocCAD was the most bought G10 FX despite outflows on Thursday and Friday coinciding with CPI data, as NAFTA fears eased somewhat earlier in the week. SEK saw heavy inflows despite a quiet week data-wise, seeing significant inflows around Riksbank Deputy Gov. Ohlsson's speech on Monday. GBP was bought as a hawkish MPC and news of a transitional Brexit deal might have provided some short-term support to sterling. NOK and CHF were bid as JPY saw marginal inflows, with peak buying interest corresponding to CPI release on Thursday. NZD was more or less flat on the week. USD was most sold, seeing a straight second week of outflows, as the market was seemingly set up for a more hawkish Fed outcome. AUD experienced its 9th week of outflows and was the only commodity currency sold as EUR was sold for the first time in four weeks. In EM, SGD and ZAR saw significant inflows as PLN was most sold.

subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China is to finalise rules on greater foreign ownership of securities firms by May as part of efforts in the trade negotiations with US and has offered to purchase more semiconductors from the US, diverting purchases from South Korea. (FT) In separate news, Chinese Premier Li stated that China is to further open up its doors and urged negotiations with US to speed up, according to state media. (Newswires)

South Korea Consumer Sentiment (Mar) 108.1 (Prev. 108.2). (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

UK PM May said dedicated talks have begun on the Northern Irish border with Ireland and the EU commission. (Newswires)

ECB’s Weidmann said market expectations for mid-2019 rate hike ‘are not completely unrealistic’. (Newswires)


FX

In thin news, and with a light data docket, major FX was trading off the broader risk tone. That tone was constructive, helping stoke flows out of the USD, JPY, CHF. – of which, the yen was a particular laggard – and into the EUR. That EUR strength was gradual over the course of the session, though with the single currency rising above 1.2450 there was some softness in the DAX in afternoon trade on the EUR strength. Elsewhere, while sterling was comfortably up against the USD – coming within a whisker of 1.4250 – it was down against the EUR; but with optimism of a soft-Brexit, GBP managed to perform better against the single currency than other major FX. Commodity FX (CAD, NZD, AUD) was generally higher against the buck; USDCAD continues to consolidate within the 1.2825-1.2950 range, near post-CPI lows. Better trade data kept NZD bid overnight, and the risk tone provided support, with NZD flirting with the 0.73 handle (though hasn’t successfully negotiated it in US trade). EMFX was generally taking advantage of the USD weakness, though the RUB was getting smashed on geopolitics.
 

COMMODITIES

Russian Energy Minister Novak said it is too soon to start talking about an exit from OPEC oil output deal and noted that an exit should be gradual. (Newswires)

Iraqi oil minister said expects Basra terminal maintenance to lead to exports being cut by about 10mln barrels in April. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump is said to withdraw from nuclear agreement with Iran on May 12, according RTE journalist. (Newswires)

US President Trump expelled 60 Russian diplomats in response to the Salisbury nerve agent attack, while President of the European Council Donald Tusk stated that 14 EU member states have decided to expel Russian diplomats and that additional measures are not excluded in the coming days. (Newswires)


US

Fed’s Mester (Voter, Hawk) said she sees further interest rate hikes this year and next despite seeing more slack, while Mester added that tariffs and NAFTA renegotiations pose risks to economic outlook. (Newswires)

US Trade Adviser Navarro said President Trump would like a USD 100bln cut in 2018 trade gap with China and noted that investment restrictions on China will be announced soon. Furthermore, Navarro also commented there is a good chance of getting a good NAFTA deal and that a good deal with South Korea is also likely. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer may announce a list of tariffs on China as soon as Tuesday. (CNBC)


MARKET RECAP

Overnight, Emini S&P 500 futures found support at the 200d SMA again, which – like in February – provided futs with a spring board. For most of the day, action was above the 2600 level, even when the risk-tone took a knock after the cash open. But the overall tone remained firm, as Trade War tensions ease following the US and China’s decision to begin negotiating trade, which led to a risk-on market tone. There were also some positive comments from trade advisor Navarro, who sounded constructive on NAFTA and trade negotiations. All sectors closed the day in the green being led by the technology sector, following Morgan Stanley raising its price target on Microsoft (MSFT) to a street high, and Intel (INTC) being upgraded at Raymond James. However, focus was firmly on Facebook (FB) after the FTC announced an open, non-public investigation on the company’s privacy practices. Since then, a Wells Fargo analyst came out with a note saying that the shares are now a buying opportunity with a price target of USD 230, which helped pare back today’s losses as they close positive. SPX +2.72% at 2658, NDX +3.78% at 6753, DJI +2.84% at 24202.

Yields were up across the curve amid a firm risk tone, with the belly seeing most of the action, with yields on 10s up c.3bps to around 2.85%. The front end of the curve was up by c.2bps. The US is set to issue $109bln (ex-bills) in 2s/5s/7s/ and 2yr FRN this week, with net supply estimated around $43bln. The supply started off on a mediocre note with a sale of 2s that tailed by 0.4bps, and cover was slightly stronger than the previous. Perhaps the most interesting story was that it was digested well considering the Treasury + Bills issuance this week is set to come in just shy of $300bln. 10-year T-note futures settle 4+ ticks lower at 128-15.

Overnight, Emini S&P 500 futures found support at the 200d SMA again, which – like in February – provided futs with a spring board. For most of the day, action was above the 2600 level, even when the risk-tone took a knock after the cash open. But the overall tone remained firm, as Trade War tensions ease following the US and China’s decision to begin negotiating trade, which led to a risk-on market tone. There were also some positive comments from trade advisor Navarro, who sounded constructive on NAFTA and trade negotiations. All sectors closed the day in the green being led by the technology sector, following Morgan Stanley raising its price target on Microsoft (MSFT) to a street high, and Intel (INTC) being upgraded at Raymond James. However, focus was firmly on Facebook (FB) after the FTC announced an open, non-public investigation on the company’s privacy practices. Since then, a Wells Fargo analyst came out with a note saying that the shares are now a buying opportunity with a price target of USD 230, which helped pare back today’s losses as they close positive.

* TREASURIES: 10-YEAR T-NOTE FUTURES SETTLE 4+ TICKS LOWER AT 128-15. Yields were up across the curve amid a firm risk tone, with the belly seeing most of the action, with yields on 10s up c.3bps to around 2.85%. The front end of the curve was up by c.2bps. The US is set to issue $109bln (ex-bills) in 2s/5s/7s/ and 2yr FRN this week, with net supply estimated around $43bln. The supply started off on a mediocre note with a sale of 2s that tailed by 0.4bps, and cover was slightly stronger than the previous. Perhaps the most interesting story was that it was digested well considering the Treasury + Bills issuance this week is set to come in just shy of $300bln.

* FOREX: DXY -0.5% HEADING INTO APAC TRADE. In thin news, and with a thin data docket, major FX was trading off the broader risk tone. That tone was constructive, helping stoke flows out of the USD, JPY, CHF. – of which, the yen was a particular laggard – and into the EUR. That EUR strength was gradual over the course of the session, though with the single currency rising above 1.2450 there was some softness in the DAX in afternoon trade on the EUR strength. Elsewhere, while sterling was comfortably up against the USD – coming within a whisker of 1.4250 – it was down against the EUR; but with optimism of a soft-Brexit, GBP managed to perform better against the single currency than other major FX. Commodity FX (CAD, NZD, AUD) was generally higher against the buck; USDCAD continues to consolidate within the 1.2825-1.2950 range, near post-CPI lows. Better trade data kept NZD bid overnight, and the risk tone provided support, with NZD flirting with the 0.73 handle (though hasn’t successfully negotiated it in US trade). EMFX was generally taking advantage of the USD weakness, though the RUB was getting smashed on geopolitics.

* CRUDE: WTI SETTLES 33C LOWER AT $65.55 (MAY '18); BRENT SETTLES 33C LOWER AT $70.12 (MAY '18). Action was thin in the crude complex, with some attributing that quiet to the launch of CNY-denominated crude contracts overnight (which rose 6%), which put some downward pressure on WTI futures overnight. Crude was trading flat throughout the US session, though around the US cash equity open saw negative ticks in sympathy with a bout of soft-risk, which weighed on equities. Some had noted that crude was stable despite risk going through phases of risk-on/risk-off throughout the session; some have explained this with reference to rising tensions in the Middle East – as seen on over the weekend, when Houthi rebels resumed firing missiles at Saudi Arabia; there were also a batch of positive OPEC+ jawboning (Russia’s energy minister Novak said it was too early to consider exiting the supply cut deal, and any exit would have to be gradual); additionally, news that Venezuela’s PDVSA was to shut three out of four refineries indefinitely (due to lack of staff as well as sweeter crude blends). Elsewhere, a note by Bernstein was getting attention, which stated that UK North Sea oil supply will resume its long-running decline next year. This week, analysts expect crude stocks to build by 400k bbls, Cushing is seen building by 2.2mln (according to a forecast by Genscape), distillates are seen drawing 1.5mln, while gasoline is expected to draw by 2mln.

PREVIEW: US to sell USD 30bln in 2-year notes at 1300 EDT/1800 GMT
content:
The US Treasury will come to market with its largest supply ever. Ex-bills, it will sell USD 109bln in 2-year (USD 30bln, Monday), 5-year notes (USD 35bln, Tuesday), 7-year (USD 29bln, Wednesday), as well as a 2-year FRN (USD 15bln, Wednesday). With USD 66.3bln maturing at end-month settlement, net supply is implied at USD 42.7bln.

The previous 2-year auction was received well, stopping through slightly. Some desks have noted a stabilisation in the short-end, as the Fed reiterated a gradual course of policy normalisation. TD Securities, suggests that the stabilisation, amid the market pricing in 3.5 hikes in 2018 should support demand at today’s auction.

Recent history (via TD Securities)

Daily FX Wrap: Chinese trade concessions and Russian vs other diplomatic expulsions
content: The DXY looks on the verge of another break lower and potential loss of the 89.000 handle amidst an escalation of Russian sanctions via the removal of diplomats from the US, 14 EU nations and elsewhere, and subsequent retaliatory moves by the Kremlin. Russia’s Foreign Ministry also issued a warning about more reprisals in coming days and was particularly scathing about the US after earlier more conciliatory developments on the trade and protectionism front with regard to China. Hence, the Dollar remains a broad loser vs G10 majors aside from the Jpy that bounced just ahead of reportedly big bidding interest at 104.50 and stops below to trade at 105.25, but eying decent option expiry at 105.00 at Monday’s NY cut and for tomorrow (1.2 bn and 1.3 bn respectively). Conversely, the Eur eventually cleared 1.2400 vs the Greenback to get within a handful of pips from nearest/strong upside resistance around 1.2446 (earlier March peak), while Cable faded above 1.4200 and Usd/Cad could not sustain sub-1.2850 territory and rebounded over 1.2900 again. The Kiwi just retained top spot vs the Usd and almost reclaimed 0.7300 status on the back of forecast-beating NZ trade data overnight, with Aud/Usd getting equally close to 0.7750 at one stage. Usd/Rub rallied on the aforementioned rise in tensions over the UK nerve gas attack, to a circa 57.2537 high and bucked the wider trend of EM gains vs the Usd on less global trade angst (relatively speaking).

JPM Equity Strategy - Hedges against further trade escalation
content:
• JPM are not convinced one should turn bearish on stocks, but below they outline the hedges that they believe might at least to some extent shield the equity portfolio from that outcome:
  • 1) Cautious stance on Tech sector, which has elaborate supply chains, is sensitive to consumer and corporate confidence, and where the adverse trade impact could be material.
  • 2) Preference for periphery over core, where DAX screens poorly.
  • 3) Preference for domestic over exporters plays.
  • 4) Preference for Financials over Cyclicals.
  • 5) Relatively more cautious stance on EM vs DM, certainly compared to the consensus. EM remains a global beta play which is dependent on trade.
  • 6) Cautious stance on commodity sectors – both Miners and Energy.

subject: DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European bourses shrug off trade concerns with China looking to step up efforts in trade negotiations with the US
content:
• European bourses shrug off trade concerns with China looking to step up efforts in trade negotiations with the US
  • A softer USD has seen EUR/USD and GBP/USD reclaim 1.2400 and 1.4200 to the upside respectively
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Weidmann, Fed’s Dudley and Mester

 

TRADE TARIFFS

Over the weekend, US Trump administration reportedly sent letter from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer to China seeking reduction of China tariffs on US autos, more access to China's financial sector & more purchases of US semiconductors, while there were separate reports that US & China are said to be discussing access to Chinese markets. (Newswires/WSJ)

China Ambassador to US stated China is looking into all options in response to US tariffs including lowering Treasury purchases, while the Ambassador reiterated China doesn't want a trade war but is ready to respond if situation escalates. In addition, there were separate comments from former Vice Commerce Minister Wei that China may look at adding tariffs on airplanes and computer chips from US. (Newswires/China Daily)

In recent reports, China is to finalise rules on greater foreign ownership of securities firms by May as part of efforts in the trade negotiations with US and has offered to purchase more semiconductors from the US, diverting purchases from South Korea. (FT)

South Korea Trade Ministry said agreed in principle with US on a revised FTA and that US agreed to exempt South Korea from steel tariffs. (Newswires)

ASIA-PACIFIC

Asian stocks began the week mostly negative as trade concerns remained at the forefront of market focus and following last week’s losses on Wall St where stocks posted their worst weekly performance in over 2 years and the DJIA slipped into correction territory. ASX 200 (-0.5%) was negative with the index led lower by its largest-weighted financials sector after the harsher losses seen in its US counterparts, while Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) fell to a near 6-month low, before staging a late rally back into positive territory. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) was weighed by trade tensions and rising Chinese money market rates (HKD 12-month HIBOR at 9-year high), while KOSPI (+0.8%) bucked the trend after news that US and South Korea agreed in principal to a revised FTA and with South Korea to be exempted from US tariffs. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued as prices failed to benefit from a risk-averse tone with demand dampened amid a lack of Rinban announcement by the BoJ, while a tier-1 US firm was said to be cautious on 2yr JGBs amid expectations for an increase in auction supply.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net drain of CNY 70bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3196 (Prev. 6.3272)

Former head of education institute reportedly confirmed PM Abe's wife was involved in land sale, according to reports citing opposition lawmakers who conducted an interview with the former institute head. (Kyodo)

New Zealand Trade Balance (Feb) M/M 217M vs. Exp. -100M (Prev. -566M). (Newswires)

New Zealand Trade Balance (Feb) Y/Y -3020M vs. Exp. -3225M (Prev. -3220M)

New Zealand Exports (Feb) 4.46B vs. Exp. 4.56B (Prev. 4.31B)

New Zealand Imports (Feb) 4.24B vs. Exp. 4.63B (Prev. 4.87B)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed’s Williams (voter, hawkish) is reportedly the leading candidate to become next NY Fed President to replace Fed’s Dudley who will step down this summer. (Newswires)

Fed’s Rosengren (non-voter, hawkish) said S&P500 index valuations are historically high and that commercial real estate valuations are quite stretched. Furthermore, Rosengren added that US has limited policy to handle shocks and that Fed should bolster its existing financial stability tools. (Newswires)

ECB’S Weidmann says market expectations for mid-2019 rate hike ‘are not completely unrealistic’. (Newswires)

Riksbank's Skingsley states that markets could see rate hikes in H2 2018. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Northern League’s leader Salvini and 5-Star Movement's chairman Di Maio are to discuss a potential plan for the Italian government (Il Messaggero). Note, that given the potential for an anti-establishment/populist government, this outcome has previously been touted as a 'market negative'.

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board (Eurostoxx +0.3%) with the exception of the FTSE MIB (-0.3%), shrugging off the negative sentiment on Wall Street and Asia dictated by looming trade disputes between China and the US. Sectors are making broad gains, healthcare is outperforming after a positive drug update from Roche (+1.6%) and energy is underpinned despite slightly softer oil prices. In terms of individual movers, Fresnillo (+5.5%) is the outperformer in the FTSE100 after an upgrade from Goldman Sachs whereas Smurfit Kappa (-4.3%) is the laggard following its refusal of the takeover offer from International Paper.

FX

Nzd/Usd nudging back up towards the 0.7300 level on a surprise NZ trade surplus and broader uptick in risk sentiment overnight as global trade war fears wane somewhat, with market contacts also reporting some decent buy orders in Nzd/Jpy as Usd/Jpy bounces off new recent lows not far off 104.50 to just over 105.00. Note, however, the headline pair has been capped amidst hefty option expiry interest at the big figure today and on Tuesday (around 2.5 bn in total). Aud/Usd is back above 0.7700 and approaching 0.7750 despite a couple of short trades of the week via crosses (vs Jpy and Cad), while Cable has breached the 1.4200 level on a mixture of hawkish BoE impulses and Brexit transition deal optimism. On that note, contacts also note some stop-sales in Eur/Gbp from circa 0.8730 to 0.8723, which is the low of the range up to 0.8743. Nevertheless, Eur/Usd remains firm and has popped above 1.2400 on extended gains from trend-line support (1.2349) and its 30 DMA (1.2337). Usd/Cad looking at bids near and under 1.2850 amidst a broadly soft Greenback as the DXY remains sub-89.500 and trade/protectionism concerns continue to weigh.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have seen a bit more downside in recent trade, to 158.59 (-28 ticks), and through interim support on some charts (158.73-70) to expose last Friday’s Eurex intraday low at 158.55 where stops are expected to target the 158.35-30 zone. Gilts are holding just above their Liffe low so far, but US Treasuries are succumbing to more selling pressure and deeper bear-steepening on an overall improvement in risk sentiment. Note also, reports that China may use fx reserves as another weapon to combat US trade tariffs via reduced UST holdings are undermining the complex ahead of hefty supply this week. However, Spanish bonds continue to bask in the afterglow of S&P’s ratings upgrade for the sovereign from BBB+ to A-, while Italian BTPs remain on the defensive ahead of auctions and amidst latest moves to form a coalition Government.

COMMODITIES

In the commodity complex, oil futures are modestly lower, albeit remaining in close proximity to recent highs, as price action is centred around China with WTI crude futures failing to hold above USD 66/bbl with demand sapped as the debut of CNY-denominated oil futures contracts stole the limelight and rose 6% in early trade. In the metals bloc, gold is range-bound at around 5-week highs as a subdued greenback and risk-averse tone kept the safe-haven afloat, while copper weakened alongside losses in Chinese metals prices in which Shanghai Rebar dropped to its lowest since July.

The 10 year bond opened at 121.69 and after a fleeting uptick to 121.74 has traded down to 121.51, 31 ticks under the previous Liffe close. Very quiet in terms of today’s UK docket with just February mortgage finance data and the first of this week’s Gilt buy-backs.

content: A mainly softer start to Monday’s Eurex session in keeping with a bout of bear-steepening along the US Treasury curve as risk-aversion abates somewhat, but the core German bond is deriving a degree of underlying support on the back of more pronounced weakness in Italian BTPs due to latest political developments – see 7.09 am headline for details. The 10 year benchmark is hovering just above the base of a 158.72-89 early range vs last Friday’s 158.87 close, while its Italian equivalent has been 42 ticks below par, although paring worst losses presently. Ahead, not much in the way of top-tier data after the final French Q4 GDP release, but comments from ECB’s Weidmann and Nouy could provide trade opportunities, while Italian supply comes at an interesting time in procedings given the aforementioned reports about a possible 5-Star and Northern League alliance.

Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
GKN (GKN LN) - Dana has revised their cash consideration for the Co.'s Driveline by USD 140mln. (Newswires) 

Smurfit Kappa (SKG LN) - Co. has rejected the revised offer from International Paper (IP). (Newswires) 

Hochtief (HOT GY) -  Co. filed a request to modify a joint bid by Abertis (ABE SM) and Atlantia (ATL IM)

Atlantia (ATL IM) – Co. said it has decided to exercise the option to purchase all or part of shares in Cellnex (CLNX SW), owned by Abertis (ABE SM), for between EUR 21.20/shr to EUR 21.50/shr. (Newsiwres)

RWE (RWE GY) – CEO Martin Schmitz said that high electricity prices in Germany could see an immediate drop if the government was to lower taxes and fees on the end customers bill, which account for over half of the total. He also expressed to be sensible in renewing ties with Russia, an important gas supplier for the Co. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Statutory auditors and independent directors at the Co. are expressing a complaint to market watchdog Consob over the move initiated by Vivendi in an attempt to prompt the resignation of 8 directors, according to Il Corriere della Sera and Il Giornale. If the regulator decides that Vivendi is to control most of the Co., the French group could be forced to launch a tender offer, according to Il Giornale and Il Messaggero. Additionally, Elliot is looking to submit a complaint with the government or with Consob against Vivendi. Shareholders in Telcom Italia might be required to appoint the six new directors proposed by Elliot on the 24th April according to Il Sole 24 Ore. A stop signal by the antitrust to a recent spike in bills, could translate into a negative impact on profits of EUR 70mln. According to Il Messaggero analysts. (Newswires)

Alstom (ALO FP) – The Co. announced a business combination agreement with Siemens (SIE GY). Additionally, the CO. has been awarded a EUR 330mln contract. (Newswires)

Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM) – CEO said that Co. is in talks with several parties interested in purchasing part of its non-performing loan portfolio. (Newswires)

Saipem (SPM IM) – A number of newspapers reported on Saturday that Poste Italiane’s CEO could become chairman of the Co. (Newswires)

Generali (G IM) – Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone increased its stake into the Co. to 3.76%, a filing reported on Friday. (Newswires)

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) - Cevian Capital are pushing for four independent units and a break up of the Co. (Handelsblatt) 

RyanAir (RYA LN)/easyJet (EZJ LN) - The UK are to crack down on hidden airline fees. (Times) 

Givaudan (GIVN SW) - Co. are to offer EUR 135 for outstanding shares of Naturex. (Newswires) 

Novartis (NOVN SW) – CEO said USD 2bln China business is to double over five years. (Newswires)

Richemont (CFR SW) – Co. has all antitrust clearances for Yoox Net-A-Porter (YNAP IM) offer. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from GKN, Royal Dutch Shell, Hammerson and Fiat Chrysler
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

26th March 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week mostly negative as trade concerns remained at the forefront of market focus and following last week’s losses on Wall St where stocks posted their worst weekly performance in over 2 years and the DJIA slipped into correction territory. ASX 200 (-0.6%) was negative with the index led lower by its largest-weighted financials sector after the harsher losses seen in its US counterparts, while Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) fell to a near 6-month low. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.6%) and Hang Seng (-0.4%) was weighed by trade tensions and rising Chinese money market rates (HKD 12-month HIBOR at 9-year high), while KOSPI (+0.3%) bucked the trend after news that US and South Korea agreed in principal to a revised FTA and with South Korea to be exempted from US tariffs.

FTSE

Hammerson (HMSO LN) – It is understood that Klépierre (LI FP) has held talks with the Co.’s top shareholders, urging them to force the firm to consider its takeover proposal. (Telegraph)

Barclays (BARC LN) – Co. has drawn up battle plans to fend off any attacks from activist investor Edward Bramson, of Sherborne Investors, who has built up a 5% stake in the high street bank. (Telegraph)

Provident Financials (PFG LN) – Co. is involved in a legal dispute with leading shareholder over alleged delays in disclosing a regulatory investigation into its credit card business. (The Times)

GKN (GKN LN) – Co. CEO has lashed out at short-term investors with the powers to decide bids, as tensions build up before Thursday’s deadline for Melrose’s (MRO LN) planned GBP 7.9bln hostile takeover. Additionally, Co.’s CEO has stated that around 25% of the Co. is held by hedge funds and they appear to be in favour of the Melrose offer. (The Times)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Co.’s chairman John Allan will be nominated this week as the next head of Britain’s employer’s group, with a mandate to help steer it through Brexit. (Sky News)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – Co.’s activist shareholders are planning to push for more ambitious goals at the May annual meeting in order to pursue a radical shift away from fossil fuels and tacking climate change. (FT)

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – Co.’s Trent 7000 engines are not affected by the issues that impacted the Trent 1000. (Newswires)

US

US MARKET WRAP: Trump signs omnibus bill amid on-going Trade Wars

* SNAPSHOT: Equities down, USD lower, Treasuries up, crude higher.

* REAR-VIEW: Trade Wars continue to feed risk-off; Solid CAD CPI; Fed's Bostic turns centrist; BOE's Vliege tilting hawkish.

* EQUITIES: SPX -2.08% at 2589, NDX -2.61% at 6508, DJI -1.77% at 23535

* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): -1.64%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -1.14%, ENERGY (XLE): -0.59%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -2.62%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -1.97%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -1.20%, MATERIALS (XLB): -1.77%, TECH (XLK): -2.17%, TELECOMS (XTL): -1.65%, UTLITIES (XLU): -1.47%.

* US equity futures experienced choppy trade today due to ongoing Trade War concerns, with China mulling $3bln worth of tariffs on numerous US products, such as steel, pipes, wine and pork which hampered stocks in early trade. Threats by US President Trump that he would potentially veto the government funding bill also kept equities on the back foot, though rallied after he signed the bill, that will keep the government open until September, though the rally proved fragile, and selling action returned as traders settled up for the week, pushing shares to session lows. During the choppy trade, the VIX rose to above 25 again, the highest since 2 March. Also, in late trade SPX broke the psychological level 2600 and headed towards the 200d ma, 2590, which it bounced off on the close. Looking to stock-specifics, S&P was being led by Foot Locker (FL) following positive earnings from Nike (NKE) after market on Thursday; Cintas was positive on earnings; and defence names (LMT, NOC, RTN) up following an increased budget for the US military.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Trade concerns continue to linger with Asian equities kicking the week off on a negative footing
content:
• Trade concerns continue to linger with Asian equities kicking the week off on a negative footing
  • A marginally softer USD led to marginal gains in EUR/USD and GBP/USD with FX markets otherwise relatively quiet
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Weidmann, Fed’s Dudley and Mester

TRADE WARS

US Trump administration reportedly sent letter from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer to China seeking reduction of China tariffs on US autos, more access to China's financial sector & more purchases of US semiconductors, while there were separate reports that US & China are said to be discussing access to Chinese markets. (Newswires/WSJ)

China Ambassador to US stated China is looking into all options in response to US tariffs including lowering Treasury purchases, while the Ambassador reiterated China doesn't want a trade war but is ready to respond if situation escalates. In addition, there were separate comments from former Vice Commerce Minister Wei that China may look at adding tariffs on airplanes and computer chips from US. (Newswires/China Daily)

South Korea Trade Ministry said agreed in principle with US on a revised FTA and that US agreed to exempt South Korea from steel tariffs. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week mostly negative as trade concerns remained at the forefront of market focus and following last week’s losses on Wall St where stocks posted their worst weekly performance in over 2 years and the DJIA slipped into correction territory. ASX 200 (-0.6%) was negative with the index led lower by its largest-weighted financials sector after the harsher losses seen in its US counterparts, while Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) fell to a near 6-month low. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.6%) and Hang Seng (-0.4%) was weighed by trade tensions and rising Chinese money market rates (HKD 12-month HIBOR at 9-year high), while KOSPI (+0.3%) bucked the trend after news that US and South Korea agreed in principal to a revised FTA and with South Korea to be exempted from US tariffs. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued as prices failed to benefit from a risk-averse tone with demand dampened amid a lack of Rinban announcement by the BoJ, while a tier-1 US firm was said to be cautious on 2yr JGBs amid expectations for an increase in auction supply. 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net drain of CNY 70bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3196 (Prev. 6.3272)

Former head of education institute reportedly confirmed PM Abe's wife was involved in land sale, according to reports citing opposition lawmakers who conducted an interview with the former institute head. (Kyodo)
 

UK/EU

ECB's Hansson said on Friday that the central bank is on track to raise rates. (Newswires)

Reports noted that Italy’s 5-Star Movement and Northern League parties are said to reach an agreement on election of parliamentary speakers, which reports speculate could suggest the 2 parties may examine a government alliance. (Newswires)

S&P raised Spain rating by one notch from BBB+ to A-; Outlook Positive, while S&P affirmed Belgium at AA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Norway at AAA; Outlook stable. Fitch affirmed Norway at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Switzerland at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, price action was relatively mundane amid a lack of data releases and as the DXY quietly languished below the 90.00 level. This helped the greenback’s major counterparts with marginal gains seen in EUR/USD and GBP/USD, while commodity linked currencies outperformed after AUD/USD found support around 0.7700 and with NZD/USD briefly underpinned in the wake of an unexpected trade surplus. Elsewhere, JPY pared back some of its recent strength amid cross-related flows which saw USD/JPY attempt a reclaim of the 105.00 handle, while HKD continued to weaken and was around 15 pips shy of the lower end of the trading band against USD which would trigger HKMA intervention.

New Zealand Trade Balance (Feb) M/M 217M vs. Exp. -100M (Prev. -566M). (Newswires)
New Zealand Trade Balance (Feb) Y/Y -3020M vs. Exp. -3225M (Prev. -3220M)
New Zealand Exports (Feb) 4.46B vs. Exp. 4.56B (Prev. 4.31B)
New Zealand Imports (Feb) 4.24B vs. Exp. 4.63B (Prev. 4.87B)


COMMODITIES

USD-denominated commodity futures were relatively quiet as price action centred around China with WTI crude futures failing to hold above USD 66/bbl on a mild pullback and with demand sapped as the debut of CNY-denominated oil futures contracts stole the limelight and rose 6% in early trade. Elsewhere, gold was range-bound at around 5-week highs as a subdued greenback and risk-averse tone kept the safe-haven afloat, while copper weakened alongside losses in Chinese metals prices in which Shanghai Rebar dropped to its lowest since July.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (16 Mar) 995 (Prev. 990). (Newswires)

China launched CNY denominated oil futures contract known as the petroyuan today. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

Saudi Arabia intercepted 7 missiles fired from Yemen in which 3 were intercepted over Riyadh. (Newswires)

South Korea and North Korea agree to hold summit preparation talks on Thursday. (Newswires)

US President Trump advisers reportedly recommend the expulsion of Russian diplomats in response to the nerve agent attack in Salisbury. (CNN)


US

The Tsy curve bulls-steepened, catching a bid amid soft risk-appetite on the back of Trade Wars fears. Yields on 2s lower by around 3bps, as were 5s, while 10s yields were 1bps lower, and 30s were unchanged in thin volume. Some analysts have expressed astonishment that 10-year yields haven't managed to meaningfully breach the 2.80% level to the downside (while the 3.00% level seems to be solidly reinforced), in spite of soft risk sentiment. One desk noted that it may be a function of shorts sitting on tidy profits this year, giving them a thicker buffer to absorb losses due to rallies. Other desks have suggested that levels near/sub 2.80% have represented good areas to add shorts. US T-Note futures (Jun'18) settle 3 ticks higher at 120-19+.

US President Trump signed the USD 1.3tln Omnibus spending bill into law on Friday. (Newswires)

Fed’s Williams (voter, hawkish) is reportedly the leading candidate to become next NY Fed President to replace Fed’s Dudley who will step down this summer. (Newswires)

Fed’s Rosengren (non-voter, hawkish) said S&P500 index valuations are historically high and that commercial real estate valuations are quite stretched. Furthermore, Rosengren added that US has limited policy to handle shocks and that Fed should bolster its existing financial stability tools. (Newswires) (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (non-voter, neutral) said he still sees three hikes as appropriate for 2018 and warned on protectionist trade. (Newswires)
